# Beneficios da natureza para as pessoas (SE)

- Constanza et al. (2014) $^1$ estimate for the total global ecosystem services in 2011 is **USD 125 trillion/yr**;

- the loss of eco-services from 1997 to 2011 due to land use change is estimated at **$4.3–20.2 trillion/yr**;

- PIB global em 2011: **USD 68 trilhões**

- controle natural de pragas e polinização providos por áreas naturais:  10-1500 dólarer/hectare $^2$

# Intensificação ecológica da agricultura

.pull-left[

### favorecimento dos organismos provedores de serviços ecossistêmicos;

   - manutenção de vegetação nativa;

   - ações de restauração;

   - adoção de boas práticas (ex. certificação agrícola)

- Os benefícios podem ser substanciais:

  - **Produtividade café pode aumentar 10 – 30%** (Projeto Interface)

  - florestas tropicais restauradas podem retirar ~3 ton de carbono $ha^{–1}$ $ano^{–1}$ da atmosfera nos primeiros 20 anos;

]

.pull-right[

```{r echo=FALSE, fig.align='center',out.width="80%"}


knitr::include_graphics("figures/coffee.jpg")


```


]

???

- dada a situação posta, existe um desafio que a gente precisa enfrentar: como produzir de forma mais sustentável;

- A gente precisa de uma intensificação ecológica da agriculutra: ou seja, favorecer os organimos que provêem os SE.

- Ações como  
   - a manutenção de áreas de vegetação nativa;
   - restaurar áreas degradadas em paisagens agrícolas;
   - Adoção de boas práticas agrícolas, o que é cobrado por ex nos produtos agrícolas certificados -- vou falar mais pra frente sobre isso.
   
- Os benefícios dessas práticas podem ser importantes!

- Pro café por ex, os dados do Projeto em que meu doutorado está inserido, obtido por colegas mostram um aumento de produtividade entre 10-30% com a polinização.

- Na foto a gente vê uma abelha nativa polinizando uma flor de café, que depois vai gerar os frutos.

- Além disso, restaurar florestas em áreas agrícolas retira até 3 toneladas carbono da atmosfera por ha, reduzindo os efeitos do aquecimento global;

# No Brasil: Lei de Proteção da Vegetação Nativa

```{r echo=FALSE, fig.align='center',out.width="75%"}

```

.footnote[
*https://g1.globo.com/politica/noticia/2011/12/entenda-principais-mudancas-no-novo-codigo-florestal.html*
]


???

A lei que regulamenta a proteção da vegetação no Brasil foi lançada na versão mais atual em 2012;

- Existem duas formas de proteção:

 - as áreas de proteção permanente, que são áreas sensíveis como topos de morro e beiras de rios;
 
 - as reservas legais, que são uma parcela da propriedade que deve ser protegida;
 
A soma de APP + RL deve ser equivalente a 20% da propriedade na maioria do território, com exceção da Amazônia.

As APP tem que ser necessariamente recuperadas pra propriedades médias e grandes. 

No caso das RL, elas podem ser recuperadas -- caso a propriedade tenha menos de 20% de cobertura -- ou uma área equivalente pode ser compensada fora da propriedade.

- The major drivers influencing Legal Reserve allocation are vegetation infarm,
property size, transportation costs, and agricultural suitability. 

- Landownders with larger properties that have lower agricultural suitability, higher transportation costs and more vegetation in farm are more likely to invest in Legal reserves. 

- This suggests that economic processes are the primary driver determining landowner
decisions around investment in Legal Reserves.

- We also show that farmers owning properties with low vegetation cover are unlikely to invest in in-farm restoration to achieve Legal Reserve compliance, instead opting for compensation schemes such as purchase credits to compensate their vegetation deficit on other properties. 

- Decisions based on these criteria will result in the concentration of Legal Reserves and native vegetation in private properties of lower agricultural value in the future, while leaving a large number of properties with few areas of forest under protection.

- This replicates biases in the spatial distribution of public protected areas

# Resultados e Discussão

- Forest restoration costs can be offset by yield and production increases. This was true when farms had >10% forest cover at the baseline and forest cover was up to 25% by the end;

- Farmers who had historically deforested less had a net financial benefit;

- There is a clear threshold around 25% forest cover above which additional restoration substantially increases costs;

- $CO_2$ prices are not enough to offset costs. Values would have to be substantially higher

Agricultural sustainable standards are an important non-state governance intervention to reduce commodities pressures on biodiversity (LENZEN et al., 2012).

In a certification process, a set of criteria of best practices on economic, social, and environmental aspects are defined and used to monitor and certify farmers (LAMBIN; THORLAKSON, 2018). The label gives farmers access to a market of consumers willing to pay a higher price for prime products (FERRARO; UCHIDA;
CONRAD, 2005). Often, this translates into economic gains for farmers and positive social and, potentially, environmental outcomes (MEEMKEN et al., 2021; OYA; SCHAEFER; SKALIDOU, 2018). Despite this, conservation benefits derived from certification are less clear (BLACKMAN; RIVERA, 2011; MEEMKEN et al., 2021).
Even though evidence on the positive biodiversity conservation impact of certification has been advocated [e.g. Haggar et al. (2015); hardt_does_2015 ], there is still uncertainty of whether or not observed differences can be attributed to sustainable standards or if some pre-existing conditions are impacting the results (MEEMKEN
et al., 2021)

# Resultados e Discussão

- Fazendas certificadas restauram mais suas APPs (sinergia entre legislação e mecanísmos voluntários);

- Para outras variáveis, falta de efeito se relaciona `a características regionais;

- Ausência de efeito no Cerrado também;

- Efeitos mais intensos poderiam se verificar em regiões onde a certificação ainda não alcança;

- Mesmo em regiões consolidadas, ainda há espaço para aumentar adicionalidade;


???

- we did find a trend suggesting that certified farms are restoring more of their
areas of permanent protection (APP) than non-certified farms, which indicates a
potential synergy between law enforcement of the Natural Vegetation Protection
Law and voluntary mechanisms, such as agricultural certification;

- This lack of effect can be partially explained by the environmental conditions
of the study region;

- the area holds characteristics often recognized as attractive for certification programs, such as a well-established supply chain, high agricultural suitability, and relatively low environmental and social risks, in a middle-income developing country;

- falta de dif. no cerrado:
   - proportion of APPs covered with vegetation was considerably higher for properties at this biome;
   - Secondly, properties at the Cerrado have more regular terrain;
   - municipalities in the Atlantic Forest are not only subjected to more strict environmental legislation, but they also possibly face more rigorous environmental surveillance due to higher environmental police contingents and higher civil society awareness in the region. Also, in relation to the Cerrado, the Atlantic Forest has a longer and wider experience on restoration projects that includes knowledge accumulation through scientific and technical research;
   - Disproportional benefits from certification could be achieved in places with
weaker governance, such as agricultural frontiers or low-income countries;
   - there is still room to increase its positive environmental impact in consolidated agricultural landscapes, as we have shown in this study. In this case, certification agencies could take advantage of local environmental legislation compliance, identifying the weaknesses and difficulties of its implementation by landowners, and facilitating its compliance.
   - By increasing farm profit, certification schemes can at least partially account for the social costs of changes, and thus promote vegetation conservation in agricultural
landscapes;
   - certifiers could stimulate within farm restoration. However, while there can be benefits on the long run, the costs at the short term are substantial. To attenuate the costs, market mechanism such as payment for ecosystem services have already been used in the Atlantic Forest to stimulate restoration (RUGGIERO et al., 2019) and could be an option, combined with complementary policies such as subsidies and technical assistance;
